|» input_audio_transcription|body|object|false|Configuration for input audio transcription, defaults to off and can be  set to `null` to turn off once on. Input audio transcription is not native to the model, since the model consumes audio directly. Transcription runs  asynchronously through [the /audio/transcriptions endpoint](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/audio/createTranscription) and should be treated as guidance of input audio content rather than precisely what the model heard. The client can optionally set the language and prompt for transcription, these offer additional guidance to the transcription service.|
|»» model|body|string|false|The model to use for transcription, current options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1`.|
|»» language|body|string|false|The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in|
|»» prompt|body|string|false|An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio|
|» turn_detection|body|object|false|Configuration for turn detection, ether Server VAD or Semantic VAD. This can be set to `null` to turn off, in which case the client must manually trigger model response.|
|»» type|body|string|false|Type of turn detection.|
|»» eagerness|body|string|false|Used only for `semantic_vad` mode. The eagerness of the model to respond. `low` will wait longer for the user to continue speaking, `high` will respond more quickly. `auto` is the default and is equivalent to `medium`.|
|»» threshold|body|number|false|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A |
|»» prefix_padding_ms|body|integer|false|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in |
|»» silence_duration_ms|body|integer|false|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). Defaults |
|»» create_response|body|boolean|false|Whether or not to automatically generate a response when a VAD stop event occurs.|
|»» interrupt_response|body|boolean|false|Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default|
|» input_audio_noise_reduction|body|object|false|Configuration for input audio noise reduction. This can be set to `null` to turn off.|
|»» type|body|string|false|Type of noise reduction. `near_field` is for close-talking microphones such as headphones, `far_field` is for far-field microphones such as laptop or conference room microphones.|
|» tools|body|[object]|false|Tools (functions) available to the model.|
|»» type|body|string|false|The type of the tool, i.e. `function`.|
|»» name|body|string|false|The name of the function.|
|»» description|body|string|false|The description of the function, including guidance on when and how |
|»» parameters|body|object|false|Parameters of the function in JSON Schema.|
|» tool_choice|body|string|false|How the model chooses tools. Options are `auto`, `none`, `required`, or |
|» temperature|body|number|false|Sampling temperature for the model, limited to [0.6, 1.2]. For audio models a temperature of 0.8 is highly recommended for best performance.|
|» max_response_output_tokens|body|any|false|Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response,|
|»» *anonymous*|body|integer|false|none|
|»» *anonymous*|body|string|false|none|

#### Detailed descriptions

**» modalities**: The set of modalities the model can respond with. To disable audio,
set this to ["text"].

**» instructions**: The default system instructions (i.e. system message) prepended to model  calls. This field allows the client to guide the model on desired  responses. The model can be instructed on response content and format,  (e.g. "be extremely succinct", "act friendly", "here are examples of good  responses") and on audio behavior (e.g. "talk quickly", "inject emotion  into your voice", "laugh frequently"). The instructions are not guaranteed  to be followed by the model, but they provide guidance to the model on the desired behavior.

Note that the server sets default instructions which will be used if this  field is not set and are visible in the `session.created` event at the  start of the session.

**» input_audio_format**: The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
For `pcm16`, input audio must be 16-bit PCM at a 24kHz sample rate, 
single channel (mono), and little-endian byte order.

**» output_audio_format**: The format of output audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
For `pcm16`, output audio is sampled at a rate of 24kHz.

**»» language**: The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in
[ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format
will improve accuracy and latency.

**»» prompt**: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio
segment.
For `whisper-1`, the [prompt is a list of keywords](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting).
For `gpt-4o-transcribe` models, the prompt is a free text string, for example "expect words related to technology".

**» turn_detection**: Configuration for turn detection, ether Server VAD or Semantic VAD. This can be set to `null` to turn off, in which case the client must manually trigger model response.
Server VAD means that the model will detect the start and end of speech based on audio volume and respond at the end of user speech.
Semantic VAD is more advanced and uses a turn detection model (in conjuction with VAD) to semantically estimate whether the user has finished speaking, then dynamically sets a timeout based on this probability. For example, if user audio trails off with "uhhm", the model will score a low probability of turn end and wait longer for the user to continue speaking. This can be useful for more natural conversations, but may have a higher latency.

**»» threshold**: Used only for `server_vad` mode. Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A 
higher threshold will require louder audio to activate the model, and 
thus might perform better in noisy environments.

**»» prefix_padding_ms**: Used only for `server_vad` mode. Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in 
milliseconds). Defaults to 300ms.

**»» silence_duration_ms**: Used only for `server_vad` mode. Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). Defaults 
to 500ms. With shorter values the model will respond more quickly, 
but may jump in on short pauses from the user.

**»» interrupt_response**: Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default
conversation (i.e. `conversation` of `auto`) when a VAD start event occurs.

**» input_audio_noise_reduction**: Configuration for input audio noise reduction. This can be set to `null` to turn off.
Noise reduction filters audio added to the input audio buffer before it is sent to VAD and the model.
Filtering the audio can improve VAD and turn detection accuracy (reducing false positives) and model performance by improving perception of the input audio.

**»» description**: The description of the function, including guidance on when and how 
to call it, and guidance about what to tell the user when calling 
(if anything).

**» tool_choice**: How the model chooses tools. Options are `auto`, `none`, `required`, or 
specify a function.

**» max_response_output_tokens**: Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response,
inclusive of tool calls. Provide an integer between 1 and 4096 to
limit output tokens, or `inf` for the maximum available tokens for a
given model. Defaults to `inf`.

#### Enumerated Values

|Parameter|Value|
|---|---|
|» modalities|text|
|» modalities|audio|
|» model|gpt-4o-realtime-preview|
|» model|gpt-4o-realtime-preview-2024-10-01|
|» model|gpt-4o-realtime-preview-2024-12-17|
|» model|gpt-4o-mini-realtime-preview|
|» model|gpt-4o-mini-realtime-preview-2024-12-17|
|»» *anonymous*|alloy|
|»» *anonymous*|ash|
|»» *anonymous*|ballad|
|»» *anonymous*|coral|

## Create an ephemeral API token for use in client-side applications with the
Realtime API specifically for realtime transcriptions. 
Can be configured with the same session parameters as the `transcription_session.update` client event.

It responds with a session object, plus a `client_secret` key which contains
a usable ephemeral API token that can be used to authenticate browser clients
for the Realtime API.

<a id="opIdcreate-realtime-transcription-session"></a>

`POST /realtime/transcription_sessions`

> Body parameter

```json
{
  "modalities": [
    "text"
  ],
  "input_audio_format": "pcm16",
  "input_audio_transcription": {
    "model": "gpt-4o-transcribe",
    "language": "string",
    "prompt": "string"
  },
  "turn_detection": {
    "type": "server_vad",
    "eagerness": "low",
    "threshold": 0,
    "prefix_padding_ms": 0,
    "silence_duration_ms": 0,
    "create_response": true,
    "interrupt_response": true
  },
  "input_audio_noise_reduction": null,
  "include": [
    "string"
  ]
}
```

realtime-api-specifically-for-realtime-transcriptions.-

-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|Name|In|Type|Required|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|body|body|[RealtimeTranscriptionSessionCreateRequest](#schemarealtimetranscriptionsessioncreaterequest)|true|Create an ephemeral API key with the given session configuration.|
|» modalities|body|array|false|The set of modalities the model can respond with. To disable audio,|
|» input_audio_format|body|string|false|The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.|
|» input_audio_transcription|body|object|false|Configuration for input audio transcription. The client can optionally set the language and prompt for transcription, these offer additional guidance to the transcription service.|
|»» model|body|string|false|The model to use for transcription, current options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1`.|
|»» language|body|string|false|The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in|
|»» prompt|body|string|false|An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio|
|» turn_detection|body|object|false|Configuration for turn detection, ether Server VAD or Semantic VAD. This can be set to `null` to turn off, in which case the client must manually trigger model response.|
|»» type|body|string|false|Type of turn detection.|
|»» eagerness|body|string|false|Used only for `semantic_vad` mode. The eagerness of the model to respond. `low` will wait longer for the user to continue speaking, `high` will respond more quickly. `auto` is the default and is equivalent to `medium`.|
|»» threshold|body|number|false|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A |
|»» prefix_padding_ms|body|integer|false|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in |
|»» silence_duration_ms|body|integer|false|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). Defaults |
|»» create_response|body|boolean|false|Whether or not to automatically generate a response when a VAD stop event occurs. Not available for transcription sessions.|
|»» interrupt_response|body|boolean|false|Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default|
|» input_audio_noise_reduction|body|object|false|Configuration for input audio noise reduction. This can be set to `null` to turn off.|
|»» type|body|string|false|Type of noise reduction. `near_field` is for close-talking microphones such as headphones, `far_field` is for far-field microphones such as laptop or conference room microphones.|
|» include|body|[string]|false|The set of items to include in the transcription. Current available items are:|

#### Detailed descriptions

**» modalities**: The set of modalities the model can respond with. To disable audio,
set this to ["text"].

**» input_audio_format**: The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
For `pcm16`, input audio must be 16-bit PCM at a 24kHz sample rate, 
single channel (mono), and little-endian byte order.

**»» language**: The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in
[ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format
will improve accuracy and latency.

**»» prompt**: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio
segment.
For `whisper-1`, the [prompt is a list of keywords](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting).
For `gpt-4o-transcribe` models, the prompt is a free text string, for example "expect words related to technology".

**» turn_detection**: Configuration for turn detection, ether Server VAD or Semantic VAD. This can be set to `null` to turn off, in which case the client must manually trigger model response.
Server VAD means that the model will detect the start and end of speech based on audio volume and respond at the end of user speech.
Semantic VAD is more advanced and uses a turn detection model (in conjuction with VAD) to semantically estimate whether the user has finished speaking, then dynamically sets a timeout based on this probability. For example, if user audio trails off with "uhhm", the model will score a low probability of turn end and wait longer for the user to continue speaking. This can be useful for more natural conversations, but may have a higher latency.

**»» threshold**: Used only for `server_vad` mode. Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A 
higher threshold will require louder audio to activate the model, and 
thus might perform better in noisy environments.

**»» prefix_padding_ms**: Used only for `server_vad` mode. Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in 
milliseconds). Defaults to 300ms.

**»» silence_duration_ms**: Used only for `server_vad` mode. Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). Defaults 
to 500ms. With shorter values the model will respond more quickly, 
but may jump in on short pauses from the user.

**»» interrupt_response**: Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default
conversation (i.e. `conversation` of `auto`) when a VAD start event occurs. Not available for transcription sessions.

**» input_audio_noise_reduction**: Configuration for input audio noise reduction. This can be set to `null` to turn off.
Noise reduction filters audio added to the input audio buffer before it is sent to VAD and the model.
Filtering the audio can improve VAD and turn detection accuracy (reducing false positives) and model performance by improving perception of the input audio.

**» include**: The set of items to include in the transcription. Current available items are:
- `item.input_audio_transcription.logprobs`

|» modalities|audio|
|» input_audio_format|pcm16|
|» input_audio_format|g711_ulaw|
|» input_audio_format|g711_alaw|
|»» model|gpt-4o-transcribe|
|»» model|gpt-4o-mini-transcribe|
|»» model|whisper-1|
|»» type|server_vad|
|»» type|semantic_vad|
|»» eagerness|low|
|»» eagerness|medium|
|»» eagerness|high|
|»» eagerness|auto|
|»» type|near_field|
|»» type|far_field|

## Creates a model response. Provide [text](/docs/guides/text) or
[image](/docs/guides/images) inputs to generate [text](/docs/guides/text)
or [JSON](/docs/guides/structured-outputs) outputs. Have the model call
your own [custom code](/docs/guides/function-calling) or use built-in
[tools](/docs/guides/tools) like [web search](/docs/guides/tools-web-search)
or [file search](/docs/guides/tools-file-search) to use your own data
as input for the model's response.

<a id="opIdcreateResponse"></a>

> Body parameter

```json
    "format": {
      "type": "text"
    }
  },

      "vector_store_ids": [
        "string"

}
```

## Returns a list of input items for a given response.

<h3 id="returns-a-list-of-input-items-for-a-given-response.-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|limit|query|integer|false|A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between|
|order|query|string|false|The order to return the input items in. Default is `asc`.|
|after|query|string|false|An item ID to list items after, used in pagination.|
|before|query|string|false|An item ID to list items before, used in pagination.|
|include|query|array[string]|false|Additional fields to include in the response. See the `include`|

#### Detailed descriptions

**limit**: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between
1 and 100, and the default is 20.

**order**: The order to return the input items in. Default is `asc`.
- `asc`: Return the input items in ascending order.
- `desc`: Return the input items in descending order.

**after**: An item ID to list items after, used in pagination.

**before**: An item ID to list items before, used in pagination.

**include**: Additional fields to include in the response. See the `include`
parameter for Response creation above for more information.

|order|desc|

|include|computer_call_output.output.image_url|

## Returns a list of vector stores.

<a id="opIdlistVectorStores"></a>

<h3 id="returns-a-list-of-vector-stores.-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|Name|In|Type|Required|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|limit|query|integer|false|A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.|
|order|query|string|false|Sort order by the `created_at` timestamp of the objects. `asc` for ascending order and `desc` for descending order.|
|after|query|string|false|A cursor for use in pagination. `after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.|
|before|query|string|false|A cursor for use in pagination. `before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.|

#### Detailed descriptions

**limit**: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

**» attributes**: Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be 
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured 
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. Keys are strings 
with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings with a maximum 
length of 512 characters, booleans, or numbers.

<h2 id="tocS_AssistantStreamEvent">AssistantStreamEvent</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemaassistantstreamevent"></a>
<a id="schema_AssistantStreamEvent"></a>
<a id="tocSassistantstreamevent"></a>
<a id="tocsassistantstreamevent"></a>

```json
{
  "enabled": true,
  "event": "thread.created",
  "data": {
    "id": "string",
    "object": "thread",
    "created_at": 0,
    "tool_resources": {
      "code_interpreter": {
        "file_ids": []
      },
      "file_search": {
        "vector_store_ids": [
          "string"
        ]
      }
    },
    "metadata": {
      "property1": "string",
      "property2": "string"
    }
  }
}

```

Represents an event emitted when streaming a Run.

Each event in a server-sent events stream has an `event` and `data` property:

```
event: thread.created
data: {"id": "thread_123", "object": "thread", ...}
```

We emit events whenever a new object is created, transitions to a new state, or is being
streamed in parts (deltas). For example, we emit `thread.run.created` when a new run
is created, `thread.run.completed` when a run completes, and so on. When an Assistant chooses
to create a message during a run, we emit a `thread.message.created event`, a
`thread.message.in_progress` event, many `thread.message.delta` events, and finally a
`thread.message.completed` event.

We may add additional events over time, so we recommend handling unknown events gracefully
in your code. See the [Assistants API quickstart](/docs/assistants/overview) to learn how to

<h2 id="tocS_AssistantsApiResponseFormatOption">AssistantsApiResponseFormatOption</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemaassistantsapiresponseformatoption"></a>
<a id="schema_AssistantsApiResponseFormatOption"></a>
<a id="tocSassistantsapiresponseformatoption"></a>
<a id="tocsassistantsapiresponseformatoption"></a>

```json
"auto"

```

Specifies the format that the model must output. Compatible with [GPT-4o](/docs/models#gpt-4o), [GPT-4 Turbo](/docs/models#gpt-4-turbo-and-gpt-4), and all GPT-3.5 Turbo models since `gpt-3.5-turbo-1106`.

Setting to `{ "type": "json_schema", "json_schema": {...} }` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema. Learn more in the [Structured Outputs guide](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

Setting to `{ "type": "json_object" }` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON.

**Important:** when using JSON mode, you **must** also instruct the model to produce JSON yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly "stuck" request. Also note that the message content may be partially cut off if `finish_reason="length"`, which indicates the generation exceeded `max_tokens` or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

|---|---|---|---|---|

xor

|*anonymous*|[ResponseFormatText](#schemaresponseformattext)|false|none|Default response format. Used to generate text responses.|

xor

|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[ResponseFormatJsonObject](#schemaresponseformatjsonobject)|false|none|JSON object response format. An older method of generating JSON responses.<br>Using `json_schema` is recommended for models that support it. Note that the<br>model will not generate JSON without a system or user message instructing it<br>to do so.|

xor

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[ResponseFormatJsonSchema](#schemaresponseformatjsonschema)|false|none|JSON Schema response format. Used to generate structured JSON responses.<br>Learn more about [Structured Outputs](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).|

#### Enumerated Values

|---|---|
|*anonymous*|auto|

<h2 id="tocS_AssistantsApiToolChoiceOption">AssistantsApiToolChoiceOption</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemaassistantsapitoolchoiceoption"></a>
<a id="schema_AssistantsApiToolChoiceOption"></a>
<a id="tocSassistantsapitoolchoiceoption"></a>
<a id="tocsassistantsapitoolchoiceoption"></a>

```json
"none"

```

Controls which (if any) tool is called by the model.
`none` means the model will not call any tools and instead generates a message.
`auto` is the default value and means the model can pick between generating a message or calling one or more tools.
`required` means the model must call one or more tools before responding to the user.
Specifying a particular tool like `{"type": "file_search"}` or `{"type": "function", "function": {"name": "my_function"}}` forces the model to call that tool.

|---|---|---|---|---|

xor

|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[AssistantsNamedToolChoice](#schemaassistantsnamedtoolchoice)|false|none|Specifies a tool the model should use. Use to force the model to call a specific tool.|

<h2 id="tocS_ChatCompletionToolChoiceOption">ChatCompletionToolChoiceOption</h2>

<a id="schemachatcompletiontoolchoiceoption"></a>
<a id="schema_ChatCompletionToolChoiceOption"></a>
<a id="tocSchatcompletiontoolchoiceoption"></a>
<a id="tocschatcompletiontoolchoiceoption"></a>

```json
"none"

```

Controls which (if any) tool is called by the model.
`none` means the model will not call any tool and instead generates a message.
`auto` means the model can pick between generating a message or calling one or more tools.
`required` means the model must call one or more tools.
Specifying a particular tool via `{"type": "function", "function": {"name": "my_function"}}` forces the model to call that tool.

`none` is the default when no tools are present. `auto` is the default if tools are present.

### Properties

oneOf

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|string|false|none|`none` means the model will not call any tool and instead generates a message. `auto` means the model can pick between generating a message or calling one or more tools. `required` means the model must call one or more tools.|

xor

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[ChatCompletionNamedToolChoice](#schemachatcompletionnamedtoolchoice)|false|none|Specifies a tool the model should use. Use to force the model to call a specific function.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|*anonymous*|none|
|*anonymous*|auto|
|*anonymous*|required|

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|

|» *anonymous*|string|false|none|none|

or

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|» *anonymous*|string|false|none|none|

continued

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|language|string|false|none|The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in [ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format will improve accuracy and latency.|
|prompt|string|false|none|An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The [prompt](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting) should match the audio language.|
|response_format|[AudioResponseFormat](#schemaaudioresponseformat)|false|none|The format of the output, in one of these options: `json`, `text`, `srt`, `verbose_json`, or `vtt`. For `gpt-4o-transcribe` and `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, the only supported format is `json`.|
|temperature|number|false|none|The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use [log probability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log_probability) to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.|
|include[]|[[TranscriptionInclude](#schematranscriptioninclude)]|false|none|Additional information to include in the transcription response. <br>`logprobs` will return the log probabilities of the tokens in the <br>response to understand the model's confidence in the transcription. <br>`logprobs` only works with response_format set to `json` and only with <br>the models `gpt-4o-transcribe` and `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`.|
|timestamp_granularities[]|[string]|false|none|The timestamp granularities to populate for this transcription. `response_format` must be set `verbose_json` to use timestamp granularities. Either or both of these options are supported: `word`, or `segment`. Note: There is no additional latency for segment timestamps, but generating word timestamps incurs additional latency.|
|stream|boolean¦null|false|none|If set to true, the model response data will be streamed to the client<br>as it is generated using [server-sent events](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Server-sent_events/Using_server-sent_events#Event_stream_format). <br>See the [Streaming section of the Speech-to-Text guide](/docs/guides/speech-to-text?lang=curl#streaming-transcriptions)<br>for more information.<br><br>Note: Streaming is not supported for the `whisper-1` model and will be ignored.|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeClientEventConversationItemCreate">RealtimeClientEventConversationItemCreate</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeclienteventconversationitemcreate"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeClientEventConversationItemCreate"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeclienteventconversationitemcreate"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeclienteventconversationitemcreate"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "conversation.item.create",
  "previous_item_id": "string",
  "item": {
    "id": "string",
    "type": "message",
    "object": "realtime.item",
    "status": "completed",
    "role": "user",
    "content": [
      {
        "type": "input_audio",
        "text": "string",
        "id": "string",
        "audio": "string",
        "transcript": "string"
      }
    ],
    "call_id": "string",
    "name": "string",
    "arguments": "string",
    "output": "string"
  }
}

```

Add a new Item to the Conversation's context, including messages, function 
calls, and function call responses. This event can be used both to populate a 
"history" of the conversation and to add new items mid-stream, but has the 
current limitation that it cannot populate assistant audio messages.

If successful, the server will respond with a `conversation.item.created` 
event, otherwise an `error` event will be sent.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|false|none|Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `conversation.item.create`.|
|previous_item_id|string|false|none|The ID of the preceding item after which the new item will be inserted. <br>If not set, the new item will be appended to the end of the conversation.<br>If set to `root`, the new item will be added to the beginning of the conversation.<br>If set to an existing ID, it allows an item to be inserted mid-conversation. If the<br>ID cannot be found, an error will be returned and the item will not be added.|
|item|[RealtimeConversationItem](#schemarealtimeconversationitem)|true|none|The item to add to the conversation.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|conversation.item.create|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeClientEventConversationItemTruncate">RealtimeClientEventConversationItemTruncate</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeclienteventconversationitemtruncate"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeClientEventConversationItemTruncate"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeclienteventconversationitemtruncate"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeclienteventconversationitemtruncate"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "conversation.item.truncate",
  "item_id": "string",
  "content_index": 0,
  "audio_end_ms": 0
}

```

Send this event to truncate a previous assistant messages audio. The server 
will produce audio faster than realtime, so this event is useful when the user 
interrupts to truncate audio that has already been sent to the client but not 
yet played. This will synchronize the server's understanding of the audio with 
the client's playback.

Truncating audio will delete the server-side text transcript to ensure there 
is not text in the context that hasn't been heard by the user.

If successful, the server will respond with a `conversation.item.truncated` 
event. 

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|false|none|Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `conversation.item.truncate`.|
|item_id|string|true|none|The ID of the assistant message item to truncate. Only assistant message <br>items can be truncated.|
|content_index|integer|true|none|The index of the content part to truncate. Set this to 0.|
|audio_end_ms|integer|true|none|Inclusive duration up to which audio is truncated, in milliseconds. If <br>the audio_end_ms is greater than the actual audio duration, the server <br>will respond with an error.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|conversation.item.truncate|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeClientEventInputAudioBufferAppend">RealtimeClientEventInputAudioBufferAppend</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeclienteventinputaudiobufferappend"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeClientEventInputAudioBufferAppend"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeclienteventinputaudiobufferappend"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeclienteventinputaudiobufferappend"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "input_audio_buffer.append",
  "audio": "string"
}

```

Send this event to append audio bytes to the input audio buffer. The audio 
buffer is temporary storage you can write to and later commit. In Server VAD 
mode, the audio buffer is used to detect speech and the server will decide 
when to commit. When Server VAD is disabled, you must commit the audio buffer
manually.

The client may choose how much audio to place in each event up to a maximum 
of 15 MiB, for example streaming smaller chunks from the client may allow the 
VAD to be more responsive. Unlike made other client events, the server will 
not send a confirmation response to this event.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|false|none|Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `input_audio_buffer.append`.|
|audio|string|true|none|Base64-encoded audio bytes. This must be in the format specified by the <br>`input_audio_format` field in the session configuration.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|input_audio_buffer.append|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeClientEventInputAudioBufferCommit">RealtimeClientEventInputAudioBufferCommit</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeclienteventinputaudiobuffercommit"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeClientEventInputAudioBufferCommit"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeclienteventinputaudiobuffercommit"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeclienteventinputaudiobuffercommit"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "input_audio_buffer.commit"
}

```

Send this event to commit the user input audio buffer, which will create a 
new user message item in the conversation. This event will produce an error 
if the input audio buffer is empty. When in Server VAD mode, the client does 
not need to send this event, the server will commit the audio buffer 
automatically.

Committing the input audio buffer will trigger input audio transcription 
(if enabled in session configuration), but it will not create a response 
from the model. The server will respond with an `input_audio_buffer.committed` 
event.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|false|none|Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `input_audio_buffer.commit`.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|input_audio_buffer.commit|

stop generating audio and emit a `output_audio_buffer.cleared` event. This 
event should be preceded by a `response.cancel` client event to stop the

[Learn more](/docs/guides/realtime-model-capabilities#client-and-server-events-for-audio-in-webrtc).

|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|false|none|The unique ID of the client event used for error handling.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `output_audio_buffer.clear`.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|output_audio_buffer.clear|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeClientEventResponseCreate">RealtimeClientEventResponseCreate</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeclienteventresponsecreate"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeClientEventResponseCreate"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeclienteventresponsecreate"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeclienteventresponsecreate"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "response.create",
  "response": {
    "modalities": [
      "text"
    ],
    "instructions": "string",
    "voice": "ash",
    "output_audio_format": "pcm16",
    "tools": [
      {
        "type": "function",
        "name": "string",
        "description": "string",
        "parameters": {}
      }
    ],
    "tool_choice": "string",
    "temperature": 0,
    "max_response_output_tokens": 0,
    "conversation": "string",
    "metadata": {
      "property1": "string",
      "property2": "string"
    },
    "input": [
      {
        "id": "string",
        "type": "message",
        "object": "realtime.item",
        "status": "completed",
        "role": "user",
        "content": [
          {
            "type": "input_audio",
            "text": "string",
            "id": "string",
            "audio": "string",
            "transcript": "string"
          }
        ],
        "call_id": "string",
        "name": "string",
        "arguments": "string",
        "output": "string"
      }
    ]
  }
}

```

This event instructs the server to create a Response, which means triggering 
model inference. When in Server VAD mode, the server will create Responses 
automatically.

A Response will include at least one Item, and may have two, in which case 
the second will be a function call. These Items will be appended to the 
conversation history.

The server will respond with a `response.created` event, events for Items 
and content created, and finally a `response.done` event to indicate the 
Response is complete.

The `response.create` event includes inference configuration like 
`instructions`, and `temperature`. These fields will override the Session's 
configuration for this Response only.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|false|none|Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `response.create`.|
|response|[RealtimeResponseCreateParams](#schemarealtimeresponsecreateparams)|false|none|Create a new Realtime response with these parameters|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|response.create|

```json
      "interrupt_response": true

    "input_audio_noise_reduction": null,
    "tools": [
      {
        "type": "function",
        "name": "string",
        "description": "string",
        "parameters": {}
      }
    ],
    "tool_choice": "auto",
    "temperature": 0.8,
    "max_response_output_tokens": 0
  }
}

```

Send this event to update the sessions default configuration.
The client may send this event at any time to update any field,
except for `voice`. However, note that once a session has been
initialized with a particular `model`, it cant be changed to
another model using `session.update`.

When the server receives a `session.update`, it will respond
with a `session.updated` event showing the full, effective configuration.
Only the fields that are present are updated. To clear a field like
`instructions`, pass an empty string.

|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `session.update`.|
|session|[RealtimeSessionCreateRequest](#schemarealtimesessioncreaterequest)|true|none|Realtime session object configuration.|

|Property|Value|
|---|---|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeServerEventConversationItemCreated">RealtimeServerEventConversationItemCreated</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeservereventconversationitemcreated"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeServerEventConversationItemCreated"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeservereventconversationitemcreated"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeservereventconversationitemcreated"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "conversation.item.created",
  "previous_item_id": "string",
  "item": {
    "id": "string",
    "type": "message",
    "object": "realtime.item",
    "status": "completed",
    "role": "user",
    "content": [
      {
        "type": "input_audio",
        "text": "string",
        "id": "string",
        "audio": "string",
        "transcript": "string"
      }
    ],
    "call_id": "string",
    "name": "string",
    "arguments": "string",
    "output": "string"
  }
}

```

Returned when a conversation item is created. There are several scenarios that produce this event:
  - The server is generating a Response, which if successful will produce 
    either one or two Items, which will be of type `message` 
    (role `assistant`) or type `function_call`.
  - The input audio buffer has been committed, either by the client or the 
    server (in `server_vad` mode). The server will take the content of the 
    input audio buffer and add it to a new user message Item.
  - The client has sent a `conversation.item.create` event to add a new Item 
    to the Conversation.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|true|none|The unique ID of the server event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `conversation.item.created`.|
|previous_item_id|string|true|none|The ID of the preceding item in the Conversation context, allows the <br>client to understand the order of the conversation.|
|item|[RealtimeConversationItem](#schemarealtimeconversationitem)|true|none|The item to add to the conversation.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|conversation.item.created|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeServerEventConversationItemInputAudioTranscriptionCompleted">RealtimeServerEventConversationItemInputAudioTranscriptionCompleted</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeservereventconversationiteminputaudiotranscriptioncompleted"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeServerEventConversationItemInputAudioTranscriptionCompleted"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeservereventconversationiteminputaudiotranscriptioncompleted"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeservereventconversationiteminputaudiotranscriptioncompleted"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "conversation.item.input_audio_transcription.completed",
  "item_id": "string",
  "content_index": 0,
  "transcript": "string",
  "logprobs": [
    {
      "token": "string",
      "logprob": 0,
      "bytes": [
        0
      ]
    }
  ]
}

```

This event is the output of audio transcription for user audio written to the 
user audio buffer. Transcription begins when the input audio buffer is 
committed by the client or server (in `server_vad` mode). Transcription runs 
asynchronously with Response creation, so this event may come before or after 
the Response events.

Realtime API models accept audio natively, and thus input transcription is a 
separate process run on a separate ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition) model, 
currently always `whisper-1`. Thus the transcript may diverge somewhat from 
the model's interpretation, and should be treated as a rough guide.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|true|none|The unique ID of the server event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be<br>`conversation.item.input_audio_transcription.completed`.|
|item_id|string|true|none|The ID of the user message item containing the audio.|
|content_index|integer|true|none|The index of the content part containing the audio.|
|transcript|string|true|none|The transcribed text.|
|logprobs|[[LogProbProperties](#schemalogprobproperties)]¦null|false|none|The log probabilities of the transcription.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|conversation.item.input_audio_transcription.completed|

<h2 id="tocS_RealtimeServerEventInputAudioBufferSpeechStarted">RealtimeServerEventInputAudioBufferSpeechStarted</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemarealtimeservereventinputaudiobufferspeechstarted"></a>
<a id="schema_RealtimeServerEventInputAudioBufferSpeechStarted"></a>
<a id="tocSrealtimeservereventinputaudiobufferspeechstarted"></a>
<a id="tocsrealtimeservereventinputaudiobufferspeechstarted"></a>

```json
{
  "event_id": "string",
  "type": "input_audio_buffer.speech_started",
  "audio_start_ms": 0,
  "item_id": "string"
}

```

Sent by the server when in `server_vad` mode to indicate that speech has been 
detected in the audio buffer. This can happen any time audio is added to the 
buffer (unless speech is already detected). The client may want to use this 
event to interrupt audio playback or provide visual feedback to the user. 

The client should expect to receive a `input_audio_buffer.speech_stopped` event 
when speech stops. The `item_id` property is the ID of the user message item 
that will be created when speech stops and will also be included in the 
`input_audio_buffer.speech_stopped` event (unless the client manually commits 
the audio buffer during VAD activation).

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|true|none|The unique ID of the server event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `input_audio_buffer.speech_started`.|
|audio_start_ms|integer|true|none|Milliseconds from the start of all audio written to the buffer during the <br>session when speech was first detected. This will correspond to the <br>beginning of audio sent to the model, and thus includes the <br>`prefix_padding_ms` configured in the Session.|
|item_id|string|true|none|The ID of the user message item that will be created when speech stops.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|input_audio_buffer.speech_started|

```json
  "audio_end_ms": 0,
  "item_id": "string"
}

```

Returned in `server_vad` mode when the server detects the end of speech in 
the audio buffer. The server will also send an `conversation.item.created` 
event with the user message item that is created from the audio buffer.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|event_id|string|true|none|The unique ID of the server event.|
|type|string|true|none|The event type, must be `input_audio_buffer.speech_stopped`.|
|audio_end_ms|integer|true|none|Milliseconds since the session started when speech stopped. This will <br>correspond to the end of audio sent to the model, and thus includes the <br>`min_silence_duration_ms` configured in the Session.|
|item_id|string|true|none|The ID of the user message item that will be created.|

#### Enumerated Values

|Property|Value|
|---|---|
|type|input_audio_buffer.speech_stopped|

Realtime session object configuration.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|id|string|false|none|Unique identifier for the session that looks like `sess_1234567890abcdef`.|
|modalities|array|false|none|The set of modalities the model can respond with. To disable audio,<br>set this to ["text"].|
|model|string|false|none|The Realtime model used for this session.|
|instructions|string|false|none|The default system instructions (i.e. system message) prepended to model  calls. This field allows the client to guide the model on desired  responses. The model can be instructed on response content and format,  (e.g. "be extremely succinct", "act friendly", "here are examples of good  responses") and on audio behavior (e.g. "talk quickly", "inject emotion  into your voice", "laugh frequently"). The instructions are not guaranteed  to be followed by the model, but they provide guidance to the model on the desired behavior.<br><br>Note that the server sets default instructions which will be used if this  field is not set and are visible in the `session.created` event at the  start of the session.|
|voice|[VoiceIdsShared](#schemavoiceidsshared)|false|none|The voice the model uses to respond. Voice cannot be changed during the <br>session once the model has responded with audio at least once. Current <br>voice options are `alloy`, `ash`, `ballad`, `coral`, `echo` `sage`, <br>`shimmer` and `verse`.|
|input_audio_format|string|false|none|The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.<br>For `pcm16`, input audio must be 16-bit PCM at a 24kHz sample rate, <br>single channel (mono), and little-endian byte order.|
|output_audio_format|string|false|none|The format of output audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.<br>For `pcm16`, output audio is sampled at a rate of 24kHz.|
|input_audio_transcription|object|false|none|Configuration for input audio transcription, defaults to off and can be  set to `null` to turn off once on. Input audio transcription is not native to the model, since the model consumes audio directly. Transcription runs  asynchronously through [the /audio/transcriptions endpoint](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/audio/createTranscription) and should be treated as guidance of input audio content rather than precisely what the model heard. The client can optionally set the language and prompt for transcription, these offer additional guidance to the transcription service.|
|» model|string|false|none|The model to use for transcription, current options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1`.|
|» language|string|false|none|The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in<br>[ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format<br>will improve accuracy and latency.|
|» prompt|string|false|none|An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio<br>segment.<br>For `whisper-1`, the [prompt is a list of keywords](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting).<br>For `gpt-4o-transcribe` models, the prompt is a free text string, for example "expect words related to technology".|
|turn_detection|object|false|none|Configuration for turn detection, ether Server VAD or Semantic VAD. This can be set to `null` to turn off, in which case the client must manually trigger model response.<br>Server VAD means that the model will detect the start and end of speech based on audio volume and respond at the end of user speech.<br>Semantic VAD is more advanced and uses a turn detection model (in conjuction with VAD) to semantically estimate whether the user has finished speaking, then dynamically sets a timeout based on this probability. For example, if user audio trails off with "uhhm", the model will score a low probability of turn end and wait longer for the user to continue speaking. This can be useful for more natural conversations, but may have a higher latency.|
|» type|string|false|none|Type of turn detection.|
|» eagerness|string|false|none|Used only for `semantic_vad` mode. The eagerness of the model to respond. `low` will wait longer for the user to continue speaking, `high` will respond more quickly. `auto` is the default and is equivalent to `medium`.|
|» threshold|number|false|none|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A <br>higher threshold will require louder audio to activate the model, and <br>thus might perform better in noisy environments.|
|» prefix_padding_ms|integer|false|none|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in <br>milliseconds). Defaults to 300ms.|
|» silence_duration_ms|integer|false|none|Used only for `server_vad` mode. Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). Defaults <br>to 500ms. With shorter values the model will respond more quickly, <br>but may jump in on short pauses from the user.|
|» create_response|boolean|false|none|Whether or not to automatically generate a response when a VAD stop event occurs.|
|» interrupt_response|boolean|false|none|Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default<br>conversation (i.e. `conversation` of `auto`) when a VAD start event occurs.|
|input_audio_noise_reduction|object|false|none|Configuration for input audio noise reduction. This can be set to `null` to turn off.<br>Noise reduction filters audio added to the input audio buffer before it is sent to VAD and the model.<br>Filtering the audio can improve VAD and turn detection accuracy (reducing false positives) and model performance by improving perception of the input audio.|
|» type|string|false|none|Type of noise reduction. `near_field` is for close-talking microphones such as headphones, `far_field` is for far-field microphones such as laptop or conference room microphones.|
|tools|[object]|false|none|Tools (functions) available to the model.|
|» type|string|false|none|The type of the tool, i.e. `function`.|
|» name|string|false|none|The name of the function.|
|» description|string|false|none|The description of the function, including guidance on when and how <br>to call it, and guidance about what to tell the user when calling <br>(if anything).|
|» parameters|object|false|none|Parameters of the function in JSON Schema.|
|tool_choice|string|false|none|How the model chooses tools. Options are `auto`, `none`, `required`, or <br>specify a function.|
|temperature|number|false|none|Sampling temperature for the model, limited to [0.6, 1.2]. For audio models a temperature of 0.8 is highly recommended for best performance.|
|max_response_output_tokens|any|false|none|Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response,<br>inclusive of tool calls. Provide an integer between 1 and 4096 to<br>limit output tokens, or `inf` for the maximum available tokens for a<br>given model. Defaults to `inf`.|

|input_audio_transcription|object|false|none|Configuration for input audio transcription. The client can optionally set the language and prompt for transcription, these offer additional guidance to the transcription service.|

|» language|string|false|none|The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in<br>[ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format<br>will improve accuracy and latency.|

This can be set to `null` to turn off, in which case the client must manually trigger model response.<br>Server VAD means that the model will detect the start and end of speech based on audio volume and respond at the end of user speech.<br>Semantic VAD is more advanced and uses a turn detection model (in conjuction with VAD) to semantically estimate whether the user has finished speaking, then dynamically sets a timeout based on this probability. For example, if user audio trails off with "uhhm", the model will score a low probability of turn end and wait longer for the user to continue speaking. This can be useful for more natural conversations, but may have a higher latency.|

A run on a thread

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|id|string|true|none|The identifier, which can be referenced in API endpoints.|
|object|string|true|none|The object type, which is always `thread.run`.|
|created_at|integer|true|none|The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was created.|
|thread_id|string|true|none|The ID of the [thread](/docs/api-reference/threads) that was executed on as a part of this run.|
|assistant_id|string|true|none|The ID of the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) used for execution of this run.|
|status|string|true|none|The status of the run, which can be either `queued`, `in_progress`, `requires_action`, `cancelling`, `cancelled`, `failed`, `completed`, `incomplete`, or `expired`.|
|required_action|object¦null|true|none|Details on the action required to continue the run. Will be `null` if no action is required.|
|» type|string|true|none|For now, this is always `submit_tool_outputs`.|
|» submit_tool_outputs|object|true|none|Details on the tool outputs needed for this run to continue.|
|»» tool_calls|[[RunToolCallObject](#schemaruntoolcallobject)]|true|none|A list of the relevant tool calls.|
|last_error|object¦null|true|none|The last error associated with this run. Will be `null` if there are no errors.|
|» code|string|true|none|One of `server_error`, `rate_limit_exceeded`, or `invalid_prompt`.|
|» message|string|true|none|A human-readable description of the error.|
|expires_at|integer¦null|true|none|The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run will expire.|
|started_at|integer¦null|true|none|The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was started.|
|cancelled_at|integer¦null|true|none|The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was cancelled.|
|failed_at|integer¦null|true|none|The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run failed.|
|completed_at|integer¦null|true|none|The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was completed.|

<h2 id="tocS_ServiceTier">ServiceTier</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemaservicetier"></a>
<a id="schema_ServiceTier"></a>
<a id="tocSservicetier"></a>
<a id="tocsservicetier"></a>

```json
"auto"

```

Specifies the latency tier to use for processing the request. This parameter is relevant for customers subscribed to the scale tier service:
  - If set to 'auto', and the Project is Scale tier enabled, the system
    will utilize scale tier credits until they are exhausted.
  - If set to 'auto', and the Project is not Scale tier enabled, the request will be processed using the default service tier with a lower uptime SLA and no latency guarentee.
  - If set to 'default', the request will be processed using the default service tier with a lower uptime SLA and no latency guarentee.
  - If set to 'flex', the request will be processed with the Flex Processing service tier. [Learn more](/docs/guides/flex-processing).
  - When not set, the default behavior is 'auto'.

  When this parameter is set, the response body will include the `service_tier` utilized.

[Learn more](/docs/guides/flex-processing).<br>  - When not set, the default behavior is 'auto'.<br><br>  When this parameter is set, the response body will include the `service_tier` utilized.|

<h2 id="tocS_TextResponseFormatConfiguration">TextResponseFormatConfiguration</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schematextresponseformatconfiguration"></a>
<a id="schema_TextResponseFormatConfiguration"></a>
<a id="tocStextresponseformatconfiguration"></a>
<a id="tocstextresponseformatconfiguration"></a>

```json
{
  "type": "text"
}

```

An object specifying the format that the model must output.

Configuring `{ "type": "json_schema" }` enables Structured Outputs, 
which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema. Learn more in the 
[Structured Outputs guide](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

The default format is `{ "type": "text" }` with no additional options.

**Not recommended for gpt-4o and newer models:**

Setting to `{ "type": "json_object" }` enables the older JSON mode, which
ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON. Using `json_schema`
is preferred for models that support it.

### Properties

oneOf

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[ResponseFormatText](#schemaresponseformattext)|false|none|Default response format. Used to generate text responses.|

xor

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[TextResponseFormatJsonSchema](#schematextresponseformatjsonschema)|false|none|JSON Schema response format. Used to generate structured JSON responses.<br>Learn more about [Structured Outputs](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).|

xor

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|[ResponseFormatJsonObject](#schemaresponseformatjsonobject)|false|none|JSON object response format. An older method of generating JSON responses.<br>Using `json_schema` is recommended for models that support it. Note that the<br>model will not generate JSON without a system or user message instructing it<br>to do so.|
